content: A train leaves New York City heading towards Los Angeles at 60 mph. At the same time, another train leaves Los Angeles heading towards New York City at 90 mph. Which train will be closer to New York City when they meet?

Both trains will be equally close to New York City when they meet.

Here's why: When the two trains meet, they are at the same point on the track. Therefore, their distances from New York City are identical at that moment. It doesn't matter what their speeds are; once they meet, they are both at the same location, hence equidistant from New York City.

To put it another way, the distance each train has traveled depends on its speed and the time traveled, but since they meet at a single point, their distances from New York City are the same at that instant.

**Final Answer**

\[ \boxed{\text{Both trains are equally close to New York City when they meet.}} \]
